name: Guided Imagery
summary: A relaxation and mind–body technique that uses visualization and sensory imagination to promote relaxation, reduce stress, and improve emotional and physical well-being.
description: Guided imagery is a mind–body practice in which an individual is directed to imagine calming scenes, experiences, or sensations to promote relaxation and well-being. A practitioner, recording, or self-practice script guides the process, often using metaphors, visualizations, and multi-sensory cues (sight, sound, touch, smell) to elicit desired psychological and physiological responses. It is used for stress management, pain control, anxiety reduction, and preparation for medical procedures. By engaging imagination, guided imagery can influence autonomic nervous system regulation, reduce sympathetic arousal, and enhance a sense of safety and calm.

treatment_variants: Relaxation imagery (calm natural scenes, safe place)
Performance imagery (rehearsal for sports, presentations, exams)
treatment_duration: Daily or weekly practice over weeks/months
metadata.training_required: Often delivered by psychologists, counselors, nurses, or certified guided imagery practitioners; training is informal and variable.
metadata.regulatory_status: Not formally regulated; training programs and certifications exist in complementary therapy fields.

contraindications: Relative: Individuals with psychosis, severe dissociation, or trauma history may experience distressing imagery; use trauma-informed approach.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Considered very safe; rare adverse experiences include emotional discomfort, resurfacing of traumatic memories, or difficulty returning from imagery if not well-grounded.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate. Supported by RCTs for stress and anxiety reduction; evidence for pain and immune function is mixed but promising.

sections.text: Guided imagery works by engaging the imagination to evoke sensory and emotional experiences. This activates similar neural networks to real sensory input, modulating autonomic nervous system responses. It reduces sympathetic arousal, increases parasympathetic activation, and can alter pain perception, reduce stress hormone levels, and promote emotional regulation.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment; comfortable posture; optional headphones or eye covering. Set clear intention for imagery (e.g., relaxation, healing, performance).
procedure: Guidance: Practitioner/script directs attention to a scene or imagery theme.
Deepening: Layer sensory detail—sights, sounds, smells, sensations.
Integration: Reinforce calm, safety, or intended outcome.
Return: Gradual reorientation to present moment.
sections.frequency: Can be used daily or situationally (e.g., before surgery or stressful events).
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies; often ongoing self-practice for maximum benefit.

uncommon: Temporary sadness or anxiety if difficult imagery surfaces
rare: Distressing intrusive imagery in trauma-sensitive individuals

relative: Psychosis or dissociative disorders (risk of destabilization)
Unprocessed trauma (can trigger flashbacks if not trauma-informed)
special_considerations: Grounding techniques should always be included.
Screen for trauma history before deep imagery work.

ideal_candidates: Individuals seeking relaxation and stress management
Patients with chronic pain or illness-related anxiety
People preparing for medical or dental procedures
Athletes and performers seeking mental rehearsal
screening_required: Mental health history for psychosis or trauma
Willingness to engage in regular practice

sections.typical_session_cost: Practitioner sessions: $50–$120; many low-cost recordings and apps available.
sections.total_treatment_cost: Low if self-guided; variable if ongoing professional support required.
sections.insurance_coverage: Rarely covered; may be included in integrative care programs.

items: Can be tailored to medical contexts (oncology, surgery prep).
Self-practice often sufficient with recorded scripts.
Encourage grounding and gradual exit to avoid disorientation.
